comments.commentBody: Sounds a lot like someone doesn't want to buy insurance for himself or pay the penalty either.  There's one more day, just go for it.

You need to read up on the legislative process.  The Executive branch is responsible for implementing legislation passed by Congress, and is authorized to make small adjustments to improve that implementation.  No parf of the actual legislated law has been changed in any way.

The ACA administrative rules and regulations process is the reason there will never be immigration reform while the Republicans have House control.  Why give Obama another law to play 'cat and mouse' with its meaning.  Thank goodness we will not be fooled again.

If theExecutive branch of govt. has the power to postpone or exempt portions of a law that has been passed, signed and reviewed by the Supreme Court -

Why can't that power be used for the good?

Add a Medicare option for all by January 1, millions will be happy to enroll and the cost should go down due to economies of scale.

First, let me make it clear.  I am a supporter of the Obama Healthcare initiative.  I just don't understand how the Executive branch of govt. has the power to postpone or exempt portions of a law that has been passed, signed and reviewed by the  Supreme Court.  Please, someone explain.
I do not see any evil Republican finger prints on this ACA, but then guilt by existing is always the game of the Democrats. 2014 will tell.
Joe - the "flawed concept" was a Republican idea. Romneycare anyone?

You must not remember well, there were several Republican suggestions but the president lectured folks that they did not know what they were talking about.  The fault is in the progressive idea that everyone needs insurance, that folks will do as they are told and that everything will work out since we know best.  Just foolish.  If they worked on improving the system and some sort of assigned risk system for those that needed it we would spend less and help more.

I wonder if many of these problems would not be occurring if the Roublicans had helped to  make the Affordable Care Act a success.  Instead, Republicans are sewing fear, and attempting to undermine any potential benefit that the health care plan might offer to millions of Americans. They care nothing for the average American. If the Affordable Care Act fails the fault will lie with the Republican Party.

When my eldest was in high school, one of her teachers -- divorced herself -- mentioned that as a loving parent, she had made the decision not to involve herself in a serious relationship until her youngest was out of high school, so that her kids need not feel confused by her own emotional entanglements nor threatened by Mom's boyfriend (the most dangerous person in a child's life is often the mother's SO). It was a lonely life, she said, but she had spared her children pain -- and eventually found her own love.

Wow, that was scary. Alone that long? But it made sense, and I followed her example.

My youngest is now in college, and I may never meet the right man for me, but this time very much alone has been essential to change and grow myself. The fact that I never introduced a potential threat into my children's lives is, as well, a source of relief and happiness.

Really, virtue -- by which I mean staying heart-free while your children grow up -- provides its own reward.

At least a dozen changes, PLUS all the waivers, each of which is an effective change of the PPACA. We have become a benana republic, says Charles Krauthammer.

While some laws have room for administrative modification of enforcement of a law, those are only in the case of the impossibility of such things as the equipment necessary to carry it out, like handicapped access machinery.
Political convenience has never been found to be a valid excuse by any court - even California's Ninth Circus.

So many people post on every Web site, even journalists who do not do any real research of what is actually covered in the plans. They just listen to the Republican negative buzz. I worked for the Federal Gov. since 1989 until I was injured as a first responder to 911/Anthrax attacks. I recruited Engineers and Architects for my office, I couldn't do that on $, since the gov's has always been 34-46% + behind the private sector on Engineering and other professional series jobs. ( I was offered $250K plus car, bonus, plus plus, when as a GS-15/10 I was making $122K. I had just had an infant at 39, and did not want to travel, and was completely in control of my own travel schedule so I turned it down, but recommended a fellow employee).

Every year I broke down the Federal plans, and listed what the benefits were. I have done the same basic breakdown with the Plans in the Exchange to help a couple of self employed friends. Here is the basic scoop. Even though their are a large number of plans in the Federal Plan, over 90% of all Federal Employees are in basically two different plans; Kaiser a true HMO or Blue Cross and Blue Shield, either their Standard which costs a family about $130 extra a month and has a $350 deductible per person, it allows you to go out side of the network but then you have less coverage. The other option is Blue Cross and Blue Shield Basic, which you must use Prefered in network providers. The exchange BCBSP Gold is similar to this. It or the Gold Kasier

And who said it was an unsecured website? One minute they are saying it is not usable and the next it is not secure. Part of the reason for the slow start has been governmental concerns about security. Stop rumor mongering. When has Medicare had security breaches? So what if they get your social security number. Put a security freeze on your credit reports by contacting the three major credit reporting agencies and the thieves cannot open a bogus account in your name. Great idea anyway. Relax.

@Connie

Everyone? Really? I think busting insurance across state lines is a very bad idea. Very bad. The only reason the ACA has so many regulations is because there was no political wil to pass anything less cumbersome--by which I mean SINGLE PAYER. Even so it's a godsend to the millions who have no insurance and don't qualify for Medicaid.

Einstein - you keep posting the Canadian comment, but you fail to realize that the Canadian healthcare plan is considered "socialism" by our Congress and would never even make it to the table for discussion, let alone passage.

If you are so enthralled with the Canadian plan (and I don't blame you), just move to Canada to take advantage of the benefit. Because until the Republicans (and some Democrats) change their ways of thinking, this will not fly anytime soon in the U.S.
Jennifer, as long as we have so many frightened, uneducated people who vote emotionally and not rationally the Republican Party will thrive.
The Republican Party made a deal with the Devil with its adoption in the 60's of the 'Southern Strategy' of relying on the racist vote. Now the bill is coming due.
They lived by the sword and so shall they perish!! But if this process can be helped along - by all means proceed!

It seems that every aspect of Republican politics is rupturing and that they have ingenuity in only thing - how to think of new ideas to hang themselves. No honor amongst thieves. If they truly cared about the electorate politicians and supporters alike would settle their differences and present a united front. Well, let them waste resources; they are the only ones who will suffer.
Inherent with every trip to the doctor is the denial of God's comment to Adam after he tossed Eve "under the bus" ... "You shall surely die."

This phrase jumped out at me: "We can redistribute money from the young and healthy to the old and sick."
Maybe there would be fewer old and sick people if more people were paid a living wage throughout their lives and had access to preventive medicine/ maintenance. (not a great metaphor but a car properly maintained lasts longer)
It's sad that the word old is so often used in conjunction with the sick.

Everyone is sick and dies eventually. That is inevitable.

Living a life of freedom by ones own values is a right commonly violated. Some people just don't value security of planning for tomorrow. Some people choose more risk than others.

We can redistribute money from the young and healthy to the old and sick.

We can redistribute money from the old healthy to the old sick, and from the old affluent to the old poor, and leave everybody else alone. This would be done by arranging the financing of health care and retirement to that effect; ERs would charge outrageously high prices and collect only from those affluent enough to pay.

Or we can not redistribute money, and some people will be sick and some die.

We could redistribute on the honor system, so that some would not pay much and say so, some would not pay much and lie about it, and the rest would try to cover any shortfall. To the extent that the rest fell short of covering expenses, people would sicken and die.

We should decide what we want to do and then look for how to implement it.

I'd rather say now would be the time to intervene with overwhelming manpower before it escalates out of control, though I don't know if the AU has enough soldiers for it, they are already busy in Somalia and CAR

and the correct expectations that monetary stimulus will fail to restore profitable demand and thus fail to restore firms’ positive real returns means that rational expectations in a liquidity trap add to the ineffectiveness of monetary policy.

But actors’ rational expectations in a liquidity trap also are or at least can be pernicious in that they demand austerity in fiscal policy, expecting that to restore full employment, which makes it difficult to do fiscal stimulus, while making such fiscal stimulus all the more necessary, because it is the only thing can change negative expectations by creating positive real returns for firms.

Finally, though combined Keynesian fiscal and monetary stimuli are the best remedies or among the best remedies for a liquidity-trap recession/depression, a persistent negative real interest rate and the reason(s) for it may blunt the restorative effects of Keynesian monetary and fiscal stimulus. My conjecture is that, whatever the reasons for a persistent negative real interest rate, whether declining population growth, lack of innovation, or something else, it may require, as Summer et al. have proposed, bubbles to inflate the economy and restore full employment, unless and until the reasons for a persistent negative real interest rate are discovered and corrected.

As you'll see, infra, we arrive at a similar place on rational micro expectations. Taking your two Neo-Keynesian post together, three things occur to me: First, Neo-Keynesians, unlike monetarist and austerians, by virtue of Keynes, the IS-LM curve, James Tobin, and recent work by you, DeLong, et al. have a consistent Neo-Keynesian macroeconomic theory that works both inside and outside a liquidity trap. Following Tobin and the implications of whether the real interest rate is negative or positive, Neo-Keynesians can produce a set of policy prescription that remedy what ails an economy: Mostly, monetary stimulus without any fiscal contraction during normal recessions with a positive real interest rate; and robust fiscal and monetary stimulus, when demand falls so low that, to restore full employment, the real interest rate is negative, which requires robust and sufficient fiscal stimulus to correct.

Congrats to you all; that is great work.

However, actors' rational micro expectations are, I think, very different inside a liquidity trap than they are outside of it. Outside of it, actors believe that monetary stimulus will be sufficient to restore the economy to full employment, and thus continue to invest and will quickly rehire workers. But, in a liquidity trap, actors don't expect and can see monetary stimulus alone won't work and thus won't invest to expand output, nor will they rehire workers. In other words, downward wage rigidity and expectations (cont.)

Some of you are missing the point. He detested using it as an offensive weapon, he created it to defend the Soviet Union. And the fact that the technology was exported was not his decision. The problem isn't the instruments of war,but rather the music of hatred that brings us to create them.

No doubt a great weapon -- whether or not you like that sort of thing -- and one that was so much better than any of its competitors that arms buyers beat a path to the manufacturers' doors for more than 60 years.

You can easily pick the handful of countries where individuals can afford (and/or are permitted) to buy their own AK-47, though, and in particular, the one where more can afford and are allowed one than anywhere else -- and the consequences of that "liberty" -- spring immediately to mind. In many other countries of late, it's been THAT very country that has often been affording the AK for whoever wants one, and might be friendly ...

As for the possibility of it being the "security that allows the impoverished the opportunity for tomorrows meal", it already has been, in many places, and will probably continue to be.

Oh, and also the not-quite-altogether-impoverished, too, and anyone else in between. It may not always be welcome when it is so employed, but it IS very democratic.

MTF, This was, without the slightest bit of doubt, the most brilliantly inspired comment you've thus far submitted to WP since joining in on the fun and pun of our highly select Xword solving society!

Howie TBOQ

seattle expat
Seattle, WA

The people of the former Soviet Union are rightly proud of this man who helped them defeat Hitler.

Dec. 23, 2013 at 10:45 p.m.
Recommend4

If you're talking about the rifle that made him famous, it did nothing to help defeat Hitler since the AK47 did not enter Soviet service until 1947 (hence the "47" designation) two years after WW II.

He did however serve as a tank commander against the Nazis and was badly wounded during the war.

You do understand synthetic fiber was first developed for paratroopers, internet was first invented for strategic C4ISR, and nuclear power comes from the research done through the Manhattan Project? "Si vis pacem, para bellum"

don't forget hook he invented the sights( interesting a snipers medal is actually the Prussian iron cross) listen the fact is it was invented -it exists and really weapons have been around for years but maybe use the technology for something else-

the fact is you could extend bullets distance and speed by designing bullets with spiral grooves that redirect wind around the bullet -but you can use the same principle on a rocket by spinning the nozzle you could encase a ship in a vacuum making it travel further and faster -i mean think how fast they would travel through space also less fuel-maybe even just using almost a slingshot to get into planets like mars orbit

hunting is a tradition and has put food on tables forever-you can do the same for cross bows-the fact is you could create laser guns that's a fact or light Sabre those are weapons to -i mean you could use a spinning firing mechanism that creates a electromagnetic funnel for the bullet to travel initially through giving that extra distance and punch at the end -

and yet look at what magnets could be used for -railroads built like trolley systems by having magnets that propel the car in front and pushes that which in turn pushes the car in front to move use a spinning cone in front to redirect wind and you have fast moving trains no friction and no fuel costs which lowers goods prices-you could use them on brakes for cars and cars themselves just by magnets pushing the wheels round and bumpers to stop rear ends

Northern liberals don't cringe when we hear Texans and Southerners talk. We have so many regional accents up here that we are used to hearing different ways of sounding out English. We don't make assumptions like you just did.

Asian émigrés have told me that they have taken voice lessons to lower their voices when speaking English.  They are successful women.  Would a man who used up talk or a generally falsetto voice be taken seriously in most professions, either?  Picture a battalion commander saying "at ease?" before addressing his or her troops.  I think Montana accents are great, by the way, Gigi.

I am a northern liberal and love hearing a southern accent.  I think southern accents sound polite and charming.  I don't think anyone's accent should be considered cringe-worthy.  Don't we all have one?

Women learn quickly that if they want to be taken seriously they have to lower the pitch of their voices and up-talk only at the end of questions. Can you imagine Janet Yellen or Christine Lagarde up-talking? A constant up-talker, male or female, often gets a prejudicial response, much the way northern liberals cringe and make assumptions whenever they hear a southern or Texas accent.

How many soldiers have been saved when their AK functioned properly without jamming, FTE, FTF, or overheating despite being inundated under muggy water, run over by trucks, or buried under sand? Sadly, some of them were not on our side.

Those civilians were military subjects of the Empire of Japan, obliged under pain of death to support the war effort. A war of conquest and genocide started by their divine Emperor. Hiroshima and Nagasaki were strategic targets due to their military operations and manufacturing.

Prior to August, 1945 many tens of thousands, indeed hundreds of thousands of Japanese civilians had been killed in conventional bomber raids. It was estimated 100,000 Tokyo residents died in one night;s bombing before Hiroshima.

The Japanese only quit after the second atomic bomb, not the first one, when it finally dawned on the divine Emperor that, after surviving hundreds of bombing raids involving hundreds of bombers each, their entire nation might now be wiped out by a couple of dozen bombers on a couple of dozen more atomic bombing missions.

The Japanese military had no idea the US was temporarily out of atomic bombs.

So the Japanese gave up, almost three weeks after the second atomic bombing, but not before there had been an abortive coup attempt ( The Kyūjō Incident ) before the final surrender.

Dear Tim McCoy,
You're nearly correct, but I have one quibble; it wasn't really the Emperor in charge. The Emperor had made no direct policy decisions since around 900 AD. There was a council of 6 making all the calls, who chose to side with the Nazis and so forth.

In '45, after the first nuclear bomb was dropped, the council was split on whether to surrender unconditionally. The only condition they really wanted was that the Emperor be spared and allowed to remain Emperor, but the U.S. needed an unconditional surrender. After the second bomb was dropped, the council was still tied, and the Emperor finally broke the tie and insisted on surrender. He expected that when he walked down to meet MacArthur, he would be executed on the spot.

Lot of miscommunication in that war.
Dan Stackhouse, Of course, you are correct in detail, still, to the average Japanese soldier on the front lines it was the divine Emperor that he was fighting desperately for.
As residents of the biggest arms exporter in the history of the world and the only one to use nuclear weapons against civillians, comments criticizing Kalashnikov sound both silly and hypocritical.
My vote's for Trotsky.  That guy had it going on.

This quote sums up the legacy of AK series of assault rifle.
"Of all the weapons in the vast Soviet arsenal nothing was more profitable than Avtomat Kalashnikova model of 1947, more commonly known as the AK-47, or Kalashnikov. It's the world's most popular assault rifle, a weapon all fighters love. An elegantly simple nine pound amalgamation of forged steel and plywood, it doesn't break, jam, or overheat. It will shoot whether it's covered in mud or filled with sand. It's so easy even a child can use it, and they do. The Soviets put the gun on a coin, Mozambique put it on their flag. Since the end of the Cold War, the Kalashnikov has become the Russian people's greatest export. After that comes vodka, caviar, and suicidal novelists. One thing is for sure; no one was lining up to buy their cars." as seen in the movie lord of war.
